'''''Lyrics:'''''[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/461/Till-the-Clouds-Roll-By/music.html "Music"] [[TCM.com]]{{plainlist| *Leonard Joy *[[Otto Harbach]] *[[Ira Gershwin]] *[[P. G. Wodehouse]] *[[Guy Bolton]] *[[Jimmy McHugh]] *Edward Laska *[[Oscar Hammerstein II]] *Jerome Kern *[[Herbert Reynolds]] *[[Dorothy Fields]] *[[Buddy DeSylva|B. G. DeSylva]] }} | cinematography = [[George Folsey (cinematographer)|George J. Folsey]]
[[Harry Stradling]] | editing = [[Albert Akst]] | studio = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | distributor = [[Loews Cineplex Entertainment|Loew's, Inc.]] | released = {{Film date|1946|12|5}} | runtime = 132 min. | country = United States | language = English | budget = $3,316,000{{Citation | title = The Eddie Mannix Ledger | publisher = Margaret Herrick Library, Center for Motion Picture Study | place = Los Angeles}}. | gross = $6,724,000 }} '''''Till The Clouds Roll By''''' is a 1946 American [[Technicolor]] [[musical film]] produced by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]. It is a fictionalized [[biopic]] of composer [[Jerome Kern]], portrayed by [[Robert Walker (actor, born 1918)|Robert Walker]]. Kern was originally involved with the production, but died before it was completed. It has a large cast of well-known musical stars of the day who appear performing Kern's songs. It was the first in a series of MGM biopics about Broadway's composers; it was followed by ''[[Words and Music (1948 film)|Words and Music]]'' ([[Rodgers and Hart]], 1948), ''[[Three Little Words (film)|Three Little Words]]'' ([[Kalmar and Ruby]], 1950), and ''[[Deep in My Heart (1954 film)|Deep in My Heart]]'' ([[Sigmund Romberg]], 1954). The film is one of the MGM musicals that entered the [[public domain]] on their 28th anniversaries because MGM did not renew their copyrights. ==Cast== {{stack|{{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 167 | header= | image1 = Judy Garland in Till the Clouds Roll By 1.jpg | caption1 =[[Judy Garland]] | image2 = Lena Horne in Till the Clouds Roll By 2.jpg | caption2 = [[Lena Horne]] | image3 = Frank Sinatra in Till the Clouds Roll By.jpg | caption3 = [[Frank Sinatra]] | image4 = Angela Lansbury in Till the Clouds Roll By.jpg | caption4 = [[Angela Lansbury]] }} }} * [[Robert Walker (actor, born 1918)|Robert Walker]] as [[Jerome Kern]] * [[June Allyson]] as Herself/Jane in ''[[Leave It to Jane]]'' * [[Lucille Bremer]] as Sally Hessler * [[Judy Garland]] as [[Marilyn Miller]] * [[Kathryn Grayson]] as Magnolia Hawks in ''[[Show Boat]]''/Herself * [[Van Heflin]] as James I. Hessler * [[Lena Horne]] as Julie LaVerne in ''Show Boat''/Herself * [[Dorothy Patrick]] as Eva Kern * [[Van Johnson]] as bandleader in Elite Club * [[Tony Martin (entertainer)|Tony Martin]] as Gaylord Ravenal in ''Show Boat''/Himself * [[Dinah Shore]] as Herself * [[Frank Sinatra]] as Himself * [[Gower Champion]] as Specialty dancer in ''[[Roberta]]'' * [[Cyd Charisse]] as Specialty dancer in ''Roberta'' * [[Angela Lansbury]] as London specialty * [[Ray McDonald (actor)|Ray McDonald]] as Dance Specialty in ''Oh, Boy!'' and ''[[Leave It to Jane]]'' * [[Virginia O'Brien]] as Ellie Mae in ''Show Boat''/Herself * Joan Wells as Young Sally Hessler * [[Harry Hayden]] as [[Charles Frohman]] * [[Paul Langton]] as [[Oscar Hammerstein II]] * [[Paul Maxey]] as [[Victor Herbert]] '''Cast notes''' * [[Esther Williams]] makes a [[cameo appearance]] * [[Sally Forrest]] and [[Mary Hatcher]] make appearances as "chorus girls". * [[Kathryn Grayson]] reprised the role of Magnolia Hawks in MGM's film adaptation of ''[[Show Boat (1951 film)|Show Boat]]'', released in 1951. File:Bruce Cowling in Till the Clouds Roll By.jpg|[[Bruce Cowling]] File:Dorothy Patrick in Till the Clouds Roll By.jpg|[[Dorothy Patrick]] File:Dinah Shore in Till the Clouds Roll By.jpg|[[Dinah Shore]] ==Production== [[File:TillCloudsRollBy01.jpg|thumb|200px|left|[[Lena Horne]] as Julie Laverne in a mini-production of ''[[Show Boat]]'', singing "[[Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man]]". ]] The working title for the film was "As the Clouds Roll By". [[Gene Kelly]] was originally intended to play Kern, with [[Gloria DeHaven]], [[Jacqueline White]], Imogene Carpenter, a stage actress, and [[Jeanette MacDonald]] in major parts. None appeared in the film. The first 15 minutes of the film consist of a condensed adaptation of Act I of ''[[Show Boat]]'', with the order of some of the songs shifted - "Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man" is sung after "Life upon the Wicked Stage", and "Ol' Man River" was used as an Act I Finale, dissimilar to the show.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} "Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man" as sung by [[Lena Horne]] was filmed, like many of her other musical numbers in MGM films, so that it could be easily removed from the print by sensitive Southern distributors.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} When the film started production in the fall of 1945, [[Judy Garland]] was signed as Broadway singer-dancer [[Marilyn Miller]], having just returned to California after a long New York honeymoon with her new husband, director [[Vincente Minnelli]]. Soon after, Kern returned to New York towards the end of October and died in November 1945. During the six months that it took to shoot the film, producer [[Arthur Freed]] had to come up with one director after another. Lemuel Ayers, a set designer, was originally scheduled to make his directorial debut on the film, but was replaced by [[Busby Berkeley]] late in August 1945. Meanwhile, Minnelli – who, it was rumored at the time, would be taking over the direction of the film – was shooting Garland's sequences even before the beginning of [[principal photography]], as she was pregnant and expected to give birth in March 1946; her shooting was completed on November 8, 1945. By the time full shooting began in the middle of December, Berkeley had been replaced by [[Henry Koster]], who was also replaced after a short period by [[Richard Whorf]]. Whorf ended up receiving the onscreen directorial credit. There was a break in production from some time in January 1946 to the middle of March of that year. The film includes two versions of "Ol' Man River" - the first sung by Caleb Peterson and an African-American chorus as part of the ''Show Boat'' medley, and the second, a "[[crooner]] version" by [[Frank Sinatra]], featured as the grand finale. [[Barbette (performer)|Barbette]] consulted on the creation of the film's circus sequence.{{cite news |last = Thompson |first = Karen R |title = "Barbette": He started in the circus |work = Community Impact newspaper |date = 2007-04-07 |url = http://impactnews.com/articles/%E2%80%9Cbarbette%E2%80%9D%3A-he-started-in-the-circus |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130208090338/http://impactnews.com/articles/%E2%80%9Cbarbette%E2%80%9D:-he-started-in-the-circus |url-status = dead |archive-date = 2013-02-08 |accessdate = 2012-08-09 }} ==Songs== {{div col}} * "Cotton Blossom" - MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "Where's the Mate for Me" - Tony Martin * "[[Make Believe (Jerome Kern song)|Make Believe]]" - Kathryn Grayson/Tony Martin * "Life Upon the Wicked Stage" - Virginia O'Brien/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus Girls * "[[Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man]]" - Lena Horne * "[[Ol' Man River]]" - Caleb Peterson/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "Ka-Lu-a" - MGM Studio Orchestra * "How'd You Like to Spoon with Me" - Angela Lansbury/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "[[They Didn't Believe Me]]" - Dinah Shore * "Till the Clouds Roll By" - June Allyson/Ray McDonald/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "Leave It to Jane" - MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus/June Allyson/Ray McDonald * "Cleopatterer" - June Allyson/Ray McDonald/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "Leave It to Jane" (Reprise) - MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus/June Allyson/Ray McDonald * "[[Look for the Silver Lining]]" - [[Judy Garland]] * "[[Sunny (musical)#Songs|Sunny]]" - Judy Garland/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "[[Who? (song)|Who?]]" - Judy Garland/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "One More Dance" - [[Lucille Bremer]] (Dubbed by Trudy Erwin) * "[[I Won't Dance]]" - [[Van Johnson]]/Lucille Bremer (dubbed by Trudy Erwin) * "She Didn't Say Yes" - [[Lee and Lyn Wilde]], aka "The Wilde Twins" * "[[Smoke Gets in Your Eyes]]" - [[Cyd Charisse]]/[[Gower Champion]] * "[[The Last Time I Saw Paris (song)|The Last Time I Saw Paris]]" - [[Dinah Shore]] * "The Land Where the Good Songs Go" - Lucille Bremer (dubbed by Trudy Erwin) * "[[Yesterdays (1933 song)|Yesterdays]]" - MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus * "[[Long Ago (and Far Away)]]" - [[Kathryn Grayson]] * "[[A Fine Romance (song)| A Fine Romance]]" - [[Virginia O'Brien]] * "[[All the Things You Are]]" - [[Tony Martin (American singer)|Tony Martin]] * "[[Why Was I Born?]]" - [[Lena Horne]] * "Ol' Man River" (Reprise/Finale) - [[Frank Sinatra]]/MGM Studio Orchestra and Chorus {{div col end}} ===Surviving Judy Garland song outtake=== A video of an excised musical number survives from this film, although part of the soundtrack has been lost. Judy Garland, as Marilyn Miller, sings "D'Ya Love Me?" to two clowns in a circus setting, representing a scene from the [[Broadway musical]] ''[[Sunny (musical)|Sunny]]''.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PfutAMxA5qk Judy Garland in outtake from ''Till the Clouds Roll By'' (1946); soundtrack partially missing] on [[YouTube]] ==Soundtrack album== [[File:Judy Garland in Till the Clouds Roll By 4.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Judy Garland as [[Marilyn Miller]] in a scene based on the musical ''[[Sunny (musical)|Sunny]]'']] [[File:Judy Garland in Till the Clouds Roll By 2.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Garland as Miller, singing "[[Who? (song)|Who?]]" from ''Sunny'']] [[File:Till the clouds roll by-judy garland.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Garland, as Miller, singing "[[Look for the Silver Lining]]" from the musical ''[[Sally (musical)|Sally]]'']] The film was one of the first motion pictures to have a [[soundtrack album]] released concurrent with it arriving in theaters. The soundtrack was produced by MGM Records. It originally contained four 78-rpm records featuring various artists and songs from the film and front-cover artwork by [[Lennie Hayton]]. Later the album was released on [[LP album|LP]].[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/461/Till-the-Clouds-Roll-By/trivia.html "Trivia"] [[TCM.com]] No official authorized version has yet been released on [[CD]], but several unauthorized versions have ([[Rhino Entertainment]] currently owns the rights to issue an authorized CD of the soundtrack, under license from [[Turner Entertainment]]; in the past, [[MCA Records]] and [[Sony Music Entertainment]] held such rights). This is due to MGM allowing the film to fall into public domain. ==Reception== ===Critical response=== [[Bosley Crowther]], reviewing the film for ''[[The New York Times]]'', wrote:{{cite web| title= 'Till Clouds Roll By,' Musical Biography of Life of Jerome Kern With Robert Walker in Title Role, at the Music Hall |date= December 6, 1946|publisher= The New York Times||url= https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9B02E6D71E3AEE3BBC4E53DFB467838D659EDE| first=Bosley |last=Crowther| authorlink= Bosley Crowther| accessdate= 2015-03-22}}
"Why did [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro]]...have to cook up a thoroughly phoney yarn about the struggles of a chirpy young composer to carry the lovely songs of [[Jerome Kern|Jerry Kern]]? And why did it have to do it in such a hackneyed and sentimental way as to grate on the sensibilities of even the most affectionately disposed?"
''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' began its review with a similar sentiment: "Why quibble about the story?"{{cite news|author=Staff| title= Review: ‘Till the Clouds Roll by’|date= December 31, 1945|newspaper= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] ||url= https://variety.com/1945/film/reviews/till-the-clouds-roll-by-1200414636/| accessdate= 2015-03-22}} ===Box office=== The film earned $4,748,000 in the US and Canada box office and $1,976,000 elsewhere, but because of its high cost the profit was only $732,000.[https://archive.org/stream/variety169-1948-01#page/n62/mode/1up "Top Grossers of 1947", ''Variety'', 7 January 1948 p 63] ===Accolades=== The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists: * 2006: [[AFI's Greatest Movie Musicals]] – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/musicals_ballot.pdf |title= AFI's Greatest Movie Musicals Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-13}} ==Home media== The film is one of several MGM musicals – another being ''[[Royal Wedding]]'' – that [[List of films in the public domain in the United States|entered the public domain]] 28 years after production because the studio did not renew the [[copyright registration]].{{cite journal |first=David |last=Pierce |date=June 2007 |title=Forgotten Faces: Why Some of Our Cinema Heritage Is Part of the Public Domain |journal=Film History: An International Journal |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=125–43 |issn=0892-2160 |oclc=15122313 |doi=10.2979/FIL.2007.19.2.125 |jstor=25165419 }} As such, it is one of the most widely circulated MGM musicals on home video. [[Warner Home Video]] gave it its first fully restored DVD release on April 25, 2006. ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web| title= Till the Clouds Roll By |year= 2007 |publisher= EmanuelLevy.com||url= http://emanuellevy.com/review/till-the-clouds-roll-by-9/| first=Emanuel |last=Levy| authorlink= Emanuel Levy| accessdate= 2015-03-22}} }} ==External links== {{Spoken Wikipedia|Till_the_Clouds_Roll_By.ogg|2019-7-27}} {{Commons category|Till the Clouds Roll By (film)|Till The Clouds Roll By}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TS3t3AZVQdQ "Till The Clouds Roll By"] Full movie at BuggZugg YouTube * {{AFI film|id=25018|title=Till the Clouds Roll By}} * {{IMDb title|0039035|Till the Clouds Roll By}} * {{tcmdb title|id=461}} * {{amg movie|49964}} * {{Internet Archive film|id=till_the_clouds_roll_by}} * [http://www.thejudyroom.com/clouds.html "Till The Clouds Roll By"] at TheJudyRoom.com {{Arthur Freed}} {{Guy Bolton}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Till The Clouds Roll By}} [[Category:1946 films]] [[Category:1940s biographical films]] [[Category:1940s musical films]] [[Category:American biographical films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about composers]] [[Category:Films about musical theatre]] [[Category:Films directed by Richard Whorf]] [[Category:Films produced by Arthur Freed]] [[Category:Jukebox musical films]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]]
